direct_answer.text:
From your message, it seems like you're trying to understand why multiplication was suggested over simply adding numbers together in certain cases, specifically mentioning cookies produced per oven cycle depending on various factors. Let me clarify:

In many scenarios, especially ones dealing with manufacturing or processing goods, different aspects influence the outcome significantly but don't necessarily stack linearly (i.e., just increasing something once doesn't always increase another thing twice). Instead, their effects often interact through what could look similar to multiplication because changing one factor increases multiple others exponentially. However, remember, even though terms like compounding might suggest math functions linked to interest rates or population models, here let us stick closer to literal interpretations than analogical extrapolations.

For example, suppose if doubling the raw material leads to double the finished good count owing mainly to increased capacity use -- no new machinery purchased concurrently--you would say things worked well until saturation points came into play---where additional resources didn't equate merely thrice original counts anymore thanks mostly likely due diminishing returns effectually speaking perhaps limit set imposed externally internally deliberately intentionally maybe accidentally so forth whatever reasons may present themselves inherently obvious subtlet
